title: How to adorn your plots
text: vignette provides best practices applying SIEI recommended colors visualizations using glitr package.

title: How to adorn your plots
text: get started, load standard OHA-SI libraries used analysis. package can divided three main parts ) colors, come objects (grey30k genoa), ii) SI themes, can used quickly apply SI plot defaults, iii) helper functions, interpolate palettes apply palettes visualization. vignette focus exploring colors SI themes.
code: library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(forcats) library(purrr) library(ggplot2) library(glitr) library(systemfonts) library(scales) library(ggtext) library(patchwork) library(sf) # Take a look at what's inside the package ls('package:glitr') #>   [1] "%>%"                     "burnt_sienna"            #>   [3] "burnt_sienna_light"      "cascade"                 #>   [5] "color_caption"           "color_gridline"          #>   [7] "color_plot_text"         "color_title"             #>   [9] "denim"                   "denim_light"             #>  [11] "genoa"                   "genoa_light"             #>  [13] "golden_sand"             "golden_sand_light"       #>  [15] "grey10k"                 "grey20k"                 #>  [17] "grey30k"                 "grey40k"                 #>  [19] "grey50k"                 "grey60k"                 #>  [21] "grey70k"                 "grey80k"                 #>  [23] "grey90k"                 "hfr_mmd"                 #>  [25] "hts"                     "hts_geo"                 #>  [27] "hw_electric_indigo"      "hw_hunter"               #>  [29] "hw_lavender_haze"        "hw_midnight_blue"        #>  [31] "hw_orchid_bloom"         "hw_slate"                #>  [33] "hw_sun_kissed"           "hw_tango"                #>  [35] "hw_viking"               "light_grey"              #>  [37] "matterhorn"              "moody_blue"              #>  [39] "moody_blue_light"        "nero"                    #>  [41] "old_rose"                "old_rose_light"          #>  [43] "pantone_aqua_sky"        "pantone_blue_iris"       #>  [45] "pantone_blue_turquoise"  "pantone_cerulean"        #>  [47] "pantone_chili_pepper"    "pantone_classic_blue"    #>  [49] "pantone_emerald"         "pantone_fuchsia_rose"    #>  [51] "pantone_greenery"        "pantone_honeysuckle"     #>  [53] "pantone_illuminating"    "pantone_living_coral"    #>  [55] "pantone_marsala"         "pantone_mimosa"          #>  [57] "pantone_peach_fuzz"      "pantone_radiant_orchid"  #>  [59] "pantone_rose_quartz"     "pantone_sand_dollar"     #>  [61] "pantone_serenity"        "pantone_tangerine_tango" #>  [63] "pantone_tigerlily"       "pantone_true_red"        #>  [65] "pantone_turquoise"       "pantone_ultimate_gray"   #>  [67] "pantone_ultra_violet"    "pantone_very_peri"       #>  [69] "pantone_viva_magenta"    "scale_color_si"          #>  [71] "scale_fill_si"           "scooter"                 #>  [73] "scooter_light"           "scooter_med"             #>  [75] "si_clear_preview"        "si_legend_color"         #>  [77] "si_legend_fill"          "si_palettes"             #>  [79] "si_preview"              "si_rampr"                #>  [81] "si_save" "si_style_xyline"         #>  [89] "si_style_ygrid"          "si_style_yline"          #>  [91] "suva_grey"               "trolley_grey"            #>  [93] "trolley_grey_light"      "usaid_black" "usaid_red"               "wapo_dblue"              #> [103] "wapo_dmauve"             "wapo_dorange"            #> [105] "wapo_lblue"              "wapo_lgreen"             #> [107] "wapo_lmauve" title: How to adorn your plots
text: number pre-defined colors come glitr package. objects starting ‘grey’ belong family gray colors grey10k lightest grey90k darkest. Objects starting usaid_ official USAID colors starting wapo_ Washington Post inspired colors. seie_ colors largely style included posterity. color_denote objects can used filling captions, gridlines, plot text plot titles. family ofcolor_` objects follows colors recommended style guide. set colors probably interest SIEI recommended colors. may recall Data Visualization Style Guild, SI team created seven core colors: denim (#2057a7) old_rose (#c43d4d) moody_blue (#8980cb) burnt_sienna (#e07653) scooter (#1e87a5) golden_sand (#f2bc40) genoa (#287c6f) trolley_grey (#808080)   access full list discrete continuous palettes, see si_palettes list call color palette directly using name (si_palettes$color_name). Color names singular (genoa, old_rose) categorical palettes based suggested color pairs. Color names plural (genoas) continuous palettes can applied continuous variables. attempt apply discrete palette continuous variable, color pairs recycled length vector attempting encode.   Finally, want create custom palette one color sets si_palettes list, can using si_rampr() function.
code: # Colors belonging to greys, usaid_, wapo_ or siei_. grep("(grey|siei_|wapo_|usaid_)", ls('package:glitr'), value = T) #>  [1] "grey10k"            "grey20k"            "grey30k"            #>  [4] "grey40k"            "grey50k"            "grey60k"            #>  [7] "grey70k"            "grey80k"            "grey90k"            #> [10] "light_grey"         "suva_grey"          "trolley_grey"       #> [13] "trolley_grey_light" "usaid_black"        "usaid_blue"         #> [16] "usaid_darkgrey"     "usaid_lightblue"    "usaid_lightgrey"    #> [19] "usaid_medblue"      "usaid_medgrey"      "usaid_red"          #> [22] "wapo_dblue"         "wapo_dmauve"        "wapo_dorange"       #> [25] "wapo_lblue"         "wapo_lgreen"        "wapo_lmauve"        #> [28] "wapo_lorange"       "wapo_lorange2"      "wapo_lpurple"       #> [31] "wapo_pushpop" # Any of these colors can be called by typing in the name of the color.  # The `show_col` function is from the `scales` package and is a handy way to preview a color.  show_col(genoa) show_col(c(denim, old_rose, moody_blue, burnt_sienna), borders = F) # Returns the recommended paired colors with genoa as the base si_palettes$genoa %>% show_col(labels = F, borders = F) # Returns an interpolated vector of color values around the base genoa color si_palettes$genoas %>% show_col(labels = F, borders = F) # si_rampr takes a palette name and the number of interpolated colors (n) you wish to return as arguments.  denim_pal <- si_rampr(pal_name = "denims", n = 25) denim_pal #>  [1] "#BFDDFF" "#B4D3FF" "#A9C9FF" "#9EBFFE" "#93B5FE" "#89ABFC" "#7FA1F6" #>  [8] "#7597EF" "#6B8FE6" "#6187DD" "#577ED4" "#4D76CA" "#436EC1" "#3666B7" #> [15] "#2A5EAE" "#1E56A5" "#114E9C" "#064693" "#033E89" "#00357F" "#002D75" #> [22] "#00256B" "#001C61" "#001458" "#000C4F" show_col(denim_pal, labels = F, borders = F)

title: How to adorn your plots
text: add colors graph, pass arguments ggplot2 call. work one sample data sets create bar graph positive testing results colored scooter.  Another way use colors plots assign color values new column data frame. example, say like highlight two partners conducted greatest number tests. First, create ranking variable ranks partners total testing. assign set colors based rankings.  apply continuous SIEI palette visualization, can use scale_fill_si() scale_color_si() function. example , create heat map, using geom_tile(), show testing targets vary across modality.  , graphic informative. Everything light shade scooter. case? look distribution data, see skews heavily toward 0. Many targets appear lower end, outliers really mucking color encoding. can couple things make graphic informative. scale_fill_si() function takes ... argument, can pass transformation option plot, well define new set breaks.
code: # Munge the hts data down to testing yields for a given year   hts_bar <-     hts %>%     filter(period == "FY50",             period_type == "cumulative") %>%     group_by(indicator, prime_partner_name) %>%     summarise(total = sum(value, na.rm = TRUE),               .groups = "drop") %>%     pivot_wider(names_from = indicator,                  values_from = total,                 names_glue = "{tolower(indicator)}") %>%     mutate(positivity = (hts_tst_pos / hts_tst),            prime_order = fct_reorder(prime_partner_name, hts_tst)) %>%    arrange(prime_order)  # Define testing results to be grey30k and positive results to be scooter.  # Play close attention to where the fill is placed in the geom_col() call.  # If placed inside the aesthetics, you will need to apply scale_fill_identity() to get the colors to render.   p <- hts_bar %>%      ggplot(aes(y = prime_order)) +     geom_col(aes(x = hts_tst), fill = grey30k) +     geom_col(aes(x = hts_tst_pos), fill = scooter) +     labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "HTS_TST_POS FILLED WITH SCOOTER COLOR",          subtitle = "ggplot2 default settings | Not real data.")   p # Create a rank column, then assign colors based on threshold (<=2)  hts_bar_rnkd <- hts_bar %>%    mutate(hts_rank = dense_rank(desc(hts_tst)),           rnk_color = case_when(            hts_rank <= 2 ~ denim,             TRUE ~ golden_sand            )          )   hts_bar_rnkd %>% filter(hts_rank < 7) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   prime_partner_name hts_tst hts_tst_pos positivity prime_order hts_rank #>   <chr>                <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl> <fct>          <int> #> 1 Ursa Major           14360        1740     0.121  Ursa Major         6 #> 2 Capricornus          21920        2020     0.0922 Capricornus        5 #> 3 Corvus               24430        1240     0.0508 Corvus             4 #> 4 Eridanus             36620        1560     0.0426 Eridanus           3 #> 5 Libra                64580        2460     0.0381 Libra              2 #> 6 Sagittarius          66470        3870     0.0582 Sagittarius        1 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: rnk_color <chr> # Assign colors to top two ranked prime partners and plot.  # Use the scale_fill_identity() to let ggplot2 know where fill is from.  hts_bar_rnkd %>%     ggplot(aes(y = prime_order, x = hts_tst, fill = rnk_color)) +    geom_col() +    scale_fill_identity() +       labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "HTS_TST FILLED BASED ON IDENTITY",          subtitle = "ggplot2 default settings | Not real data.") hts_hm <- hts %>%    filter(period_type == "targets", period == "FY50") %>%    group_by(prime_partner_name) %>%    mutate(total_targets = sum(value, na.rm = T)) %>%    ungroup() %>%    mutate(partner_order = fct_reorder(prime_partner_name, total_targets))  hts_hm %>%    ggplot(aes(x = modality, y = partner_order, fill = value)) +    geom_tile(color = "white") +   scale_fill_si(palette = "scooters") +   labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "UNIMPRESSIVE HEAT MAP WITH SCOOTERS FILL",          subtitle = "ggplot2 default settings | Not real data.") # Log transform data, clean up legend, apply semi-transparency (alpha) and label   hts_hm %>%      ggplot(aes(x = modality, y = partner_order, fill = value)) +      geom_tile(color = "white") +     scale_fill_si(palette = "scooters", alpha = 0.85, trans = "log",                    breaks = c(1 * 10^(1:5)),                   labels = comma,                   name = "Targets") +     labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "LOG-TRANSFORMED COLOR ENCODING",            subtitle = "ggplot2 default settings | Not real data.",          ) +     geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(value > 10000, comma(value), NA_real_)),               size = 8/.pt, family = "Source Sans Pro", color = "white") +     scale_x_discrete(guide = guide_axis(n.dodge = 2), position = "top") +   theme_minimal()

title: How to adorn your plots
text: order create visualizations appear belong family (Think Baldwin Brothers), glitr includes nine ggplot themes simplify plot core elements. base themes si_style(). can see differs default ggplot2 theme applying theme plot .  notice si_style strips background gray color converts grid lines light shade gray. plot oriented horizontally, can remove extra y gridlines using si_style_xgrid theme. si themes also come pre-formatted titles, subtitles, captions following style guild standards.
code: grep("(si_style)", ls('package:glitr'), value = T) #> [1] "si_style"         "si_style_map"     "si_style_nolines" "si_style_void"    #> [5] "si_style_xgrid"   "si_style_xline"   "si_style_xyline"  "si_style_ygrid"   #> [9] "si_style_yline" p + si_style() +   labs(subtitle = "si_style_() | Title, subtitle and caption formatted.") p +    si_style_xgrid() +    scale_x_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(caption = paste("Generated on ", Sys.Date(), " by the SI team."),       subtitle = "si_style_xgrid() | Title, subtitle and caption formatted.") +   coord_cartesian(expand = F) # Move names closer to y-axis

title: How to adorn your plots
text: summary graphic showing available SI themes.
code: # Create a list of all themes to loop over   theme_list <- list('si_style()' = si_style(),                       'si_style_xline()' = si_style_xline(),                       'si_style_xgrid()' = si_style_xgrid(),                      'si_style_xyline()' = si_style_xyline(),                       'si_style_yline()' = si_style_yline(),                       'si_style_ygrid()' = si_style_ygrid(),                       'si_style_nolines()' = si_style_nolines(),                       'si_style_void()' = si_style_void()                      )  # Custom plot function to incorporate themes   custom_plot <- function(x) {     p + {{x}}   }  # Make all the plots     plots <- map2(theme_list, names(theme_list),  ~custom_plot(.x) +                    labs(subtitle = paste(.y), title = NULL) +                   theme(axis.text = element_text(size = 12/.pt)))     # Create a sample map  hts_map <-  hts_geo %>%     ggplot() +     geom_sf(aes(fill = prime_partner_name)) +     si_style_map() +     scale_fill_si(palette = "siei", discrete = T) +    theme(legend.position = "none") +     labs(subtitle = 'si_style_map()')      reduce(plots, `+`) +      hts_map +     plot_annotation(subtitle = "A comparison of si_style() themes") +     plot_layout(ncol = 3)

title: Available Colors
text: USAID Graphics Standard Manual lays two colors found agency’s logo primary color palette, USAID Blue USAID Red. colors used “reinforce aid American people” provide limited range colors work data visualization. OHA developed offshoot colors visualization, expanding number categorical colors choose creating color-blind friendly palette (508 compliant). started Medium Blue USAID Red used combination platforms (Adobe Color, Palettable, Viz Palette chroma.js), modifying Denim Old Rose. , expanded colors full palette categorical (paired lighter version) continuous/sequential colors. Strategic use OHA palette allows consistent branding reduces time needed think color choices every visualization. said, colors used meaningfully thought given standard colors accentuate visual/message. Use USAID colors text banners, text text boxes. USAID colors available use graphs charts, however OHA palette specifically use data visualization products (charts, graphs, visuals etc.). doubt color use, try creating visualization black white first. , add colors one time data sufficiently encoded reinforce message.

title: What the f*nt?
text: Sans Source 3 (formerly Pro) open source font available Google Fonts Software Center USAID GFEs. - install GFE, open Software Center App, click “Source Sans Pro (Google Web Font)”, select install. - install Google Fonts, navigate link click “Download family”. folder finishes downloading, unzip .

title: What the f*nt?
text: order take advantage non-native R fonts, need update graphics device Global Options “AGG”. Graphics R plotted graphics device. can manually specify graphics device let R use default device. interactive R environment, default use device plots graphics screen. Microsoft Windows, windows device used.” Joseph Adler - “R Nutshell” change graphic device “AGG”, menu bar, navigate Tools > Global Options > General > Graphics > Graphic Device. , Graphic Device selected likely just “(Default).” need change “AGG”.

title: What the f*nt?
text: use non-native fonts R, must load systemfonts, installed dependency glitr. use Source Sans 3 typeface ggplot2 R, need load systemfonts library package start code.
code: library(ggplot2) library(systemfonts) library(glitr)  ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +   geom_point() +    si_style()

title: Authors and Citation
text: Tim Essam. Author, maintainer. Aaron Chafetz. Author. Baboyma Kagniniwa. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Essam T, Chafetz , Kagniniwa B (2024). glitr: Adorned SI style plots. R package version 0.2.7, https://usaid-oha-si.github.io/glitr/, https://github.com/USAID-OHA-SI/glitr.
code: @Manual{,   title = {glitr: Adorned SI style plots},   author = {Tim Essam and Aaron Chafetz and Baboyma Kagniniwa},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.2.7, https://usaid-oha-si.github.io/glitr/},   url = {https://github.com/USAID-OHA-SI/glitr}, }

title: Adorned SI style plots
text: Inspired BBC bbplot, repo contains proposed functions glitr package. installed, glitr adorns plots standardized SI style. package develops, pre-built plot types available allow make beautiful, standardized SI plots array PEPFAR indicators disaggregates. Detailed examples use functions included glitr package can found glitr cookbook. explanation install default font, Source Sans Pro, see f*nt? vignette(vignettes/--f_nt).

title: Adorned SI style plots
text: glitr CRAN, install directly rOpenSci GitHub using code found .
code: ## SETUP    #install from rOpenSci   install.packages('glitr', repos = c('https://usaid-oha-si.r-universe.dev', getOption("repos")))        #alt: install from GitHub using pak     #install.packages("pak")     #pak::pak("USAID-OHA-SI/glitr")        #load the package     library(glitr)  ## EXAMPLE WITH BASE SI STYLE   library(ggplot2)   library(systemfonts)   ggplot(iris,           aes(Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +    geom_point() +    si_style()    ## LIST OF FUNCTIONS/STYLES INCLUDED WITH PACKAGE   ls('package:glitr')

title: Adorned SI style plots
text: create standard visualizations across team, rely one USAID’s alternate fonts, Sans Source 3 (formerly Source Sans Pro). font native R, standard Windows. Sans Source Pro open source font available Google Fonts Software Center USAID GFEs. install Google Fonts, navigate link click “Download family”. folder finishes downloading, unzip . install GFE, open Software Center App, click “Source Sans Pro (Google Web Font)”, select install. order take advantage non-native R fonts, need update graphics device Global Options “AGG”. change graphic device “AGG”, menu bar, navigate Tools > Global Options > General > Graphics > Graphic Device. , Graphic Device selected likely just “(Default).” need change “AGG”. use non-native fonts R, must run program called systemfonts installed dependency glitr. use Source Sans 3 typeface ggplot2 R, need load systemfonts library package start code. Disclaimer: findings, interpretation, conclusions expressed herein authors necessarily reflect views United States Agency International Development. errors remain .

what: glitr: Adorned SI style plots — glitr-package
title: glitr: Adorned SI style plots — glitr-package
text: Helps create export ggplot2 charts style used GH OHA SI team. Includes multiple styles themes tweak plots user needs. Sample testing data also available.

title: glitr: Adorned SI style plots — glitr-package

title: grey10k — grey10k
text: One nine shades grey included. lower k-value, lighter shade. grey10k lightest grey. hex value: "#E6E7E8". Useful light reference lines, boxes areas.

title: HFR Multi-Month Dispensing (MMD) data — hfr_mmd
text: data frame 12 variables 243 rows date start month month reporting fiscal_year current fiscal year reporting hfr_pd reporting period, month number FY calendar operatingunit PEPFAR Operating Unit snu1 PEPFAR sub national unit 1 national level psnu PEPFAR prioritization sub national unit mech_code PEPFAR mechanism code tx_curr reporting period value patients treatment tx_mmd.o3mo reporting period value patients 3 months Rx dispensing tx_mmd.u3mo reporting period value patients 3 months Rx dispensing tx_mmd.unk reporting period value patients unknown months Rx dispensing share_tx_mmd.o3mo reporting period share treatment patients 3 months Rx dispensing

scale_color_si — scale_color_si
code: scale_color_si(   palette = "genoas",   alpha = 1,   discrete = FALSE,   reverse = FALSE,   ... )

title: scale_color_si — scale_color_si
text: palette Choose 'si_palettes' list alpha sets transparency color discrete whether use discrete color palette reverse true, reverses order palette ... additional arguments pass scale_color_gradientn

title: scale_color_si — scale_color_si
code: if (FALSE) { library(ggplot2) library(glitr)  # Apply palettes to discrete or continuous colors ggplot(diamonds) + geom_point(aes(x = carat, y = price, color = cut)) + scale_color_si("genoas", discrete = T)  ggplot(diamonds) + geom_point(aes(x = carat, y = price, color = price)) + scale_color_si("genoas")}

title: scale_fill_si — scale_fill_si
code: scale_fill_si(   palette = "genoas",   alpha = 1,   discrete = FALSE,   reverse = FALSE,   ... )

title: scale_fill_si — scale_fill_si
text: palette Choose 'si_palettes' list alpha sets transparency color discrete whether use discrete colour palette reverse TRUE, reverses order palette ... additional arguments pass scale_color_gradientn

title: scale_fill_si — scale_fill_si
code: if (FALSE) { library(ggplot2) library(tibble) library(sf) library(rnaturalearth) library(glitr) library(systemfonts)  ggplot(diamonds) +   geom_bar(aes(x = cut, fill = clarity)) +   scale_fill_si("genoas", discrete = T)  rnaturalearth::ne_countries(continent = "africa", returnclass = "sf") %>%  add_column(runif = runif(nrow(.))) %>%  ggplot() +  geom_sf(aes(fill = runif), color = "white", size = 0.25) +  scale_fill_si("old_roses", reverse = T) +  si_style_void()  }

title: Clear out Plot Previews — si_clear_preview
text: Cleans temporary folder temporary plots. temporary folder removed session ends, may useful remove extraneous previews taking space slowing processing session.

title: Clear out Plot Previews — si_clear_preview
code: if (FALSE) { library(systemfonts) hts %>%   dplyr::filter(period_type == "results",                 indicator == "HTS_TST_POS") %>%   ggplot2::ggplot(aes(period, value)) +   ggplot2::geom_col() +   ggplot2::facet_wrap(~forcats::fct_reorder2(modality, period, value)) +   ggplot2::labs(x = NULL, y = NULL,                 title = "Saturn experienced a drop in Index testing in FY50Q1" %>% toupper,                 subtitle = "Saturn, folks!",                 caption = "Source: FY50Q1i MSD") +   si_style_nolines()  si_preview()  si_clear_preview() }

what: SI legend for color aesthetics — si_legend_color
title: SI legend for color aesthetics — si_legend_color
text: Function attempts create well formatted color-based legend adorn existing plot.

title: SI legend for color aesthetics — si_legend_color
SI legend for color aesthetics — si_legend_color
text: helper function compliments various si_style() themes. main action move fill-based legend top left plot stretch legend. action can done using ggplot2::guides() function.

title: SI legend for color aesthetics — si_legend_color
code: if (FALSE) { library(systemfonts) library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, color = Sepal.Width)) + geom_point(size = 4) + si_legend_color() + si_style() }

what: SI legend for fill aesthetics — si_legend_fill
title: SI legend for fill aesthetics — si_legend_fill
text: Function attempts create well formatted color-based legend adorn existing plot.

title: SI legend for fill aesthetics — si_legend_fill
SI legend for fill aesthetics — si_legend_fill
text: helper function compliments various si_style() themes. main action move fill-based legend top left plot stretch legend. action can done using ggplot2::guides() function.

title: SI legend for fill aesthetics — si_legend_fill
code: if (FALSE) { library(systemfonts) library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, fill = Sepal.Width)) + geom_point(shape = 21, size = 4) + si_legend_fill() + si_style() }

what: List of SI Color Palettes — si_palettes
title: List of SI Color Palettes — si_palettes
text: Sets color palettes collected SI team. Includes colors SIEI data visualization guide additional palettes. Colors stored named list. Use palette name position call colors. Color sets stored name first color. Calling si_palettes$old_rose return five color pairs old_rose base. Calling si_palettes$old_roses return interpolated ramp 11 colors old_rose. See SIEI data visualization guide additional details.

title: List of SI Color Palettes — si_palettes
List of SI Color Palettes — si_palettes
List of SI Color Palettes — si_palettes
code: if (FALSE) { # List names of palettes available names(si_palettes)  scales::show_col(si_palettes$siei) scales::show_col(si_palettes$old_roses)  # Show palettes interpolated si_rampr("carto_div_earth", n = 10) %>% scales::show_col(labels = T) si_rampr("carto_div_earth", n = 100) %>% scales::show_col(labels = FALSE) }

title: Preview Plot Output — si_preview
text: Saves launches temporary file see sizing layout aesthetics, e.g. font size, shape size, etc, look exported IDE preview.

title: Preview Plot Output — si_preview
text: scale Multiplicative scaling factor. width plot width inches, default = 10 height plot height inches, default = 5.625 dpi plot resolution ... additional arguments pass ggsave

title: Preview Plot Output — si_preview
code: if (FALSE) { library(systemfonts) hts %>%   dplyr::filter(period_type == "results",                 indicator == "HTS_TST_POS") %>%   ggplot2::ggplot(aes(period, value)) +   ggplot2::geom_col() +   ggplot2::facet_wrap(~forcats::fct_reorder2(modality, period, value)) +   ggplot2::labs(x = NULL, y = NULL,                 title = "Saturn experienced a drop in Index testing in FY50Q1" %>% toupper,                 subtitle = "Saturn, folks!",                 caption = "Source: FY50Q1i MSD") +   si_style_nolines()  si_preview()  si_clear_preview() }

title: Palette interpolation — si_rampr
text: Generate palette linear interpolation. discrete palette selected, colors recycled length desired vector.

title: Palette interpolation — si_rampr
text: pal_name name palette n number interpolation points alpha sets transparency color reverse true, reverses order

title: Palette interpolation — si_rampr
code: if (FALSE) { #View different interpolations of palettes si_rampr("royals") %>%  scales::show_col() si_rampr("royals", n = 10) %>% scales::show_col() si_rampr("royals", n = 100) }

title: Save Plot — si_save
code: si_save(   filename,   plot = last_plot(),   path = NULL,   scale = 1,   width = 10,   height = 5.625,   dpi = 320,   ... )

title: Save Plot — si_save
text: filename File name create disk, png unless otherwise specified plot Plot save, defaults last plot displayed. path Path directory save plot : path filename combined create fully qualified file name. Defaults working directory. scale Multiplicative scaling factor. width plot width inches, default = 10 height plot height inches, default = 5.625 dpi plot resolution ... additional arguments pass ggsave

title: Save Plot — si_save
code: if (FALSE) { library(systemfonts) library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +   geom_point() + si_style() #default save si_save("out/sepal.png") #defaults to png if not specified (.pdf, .svg, .jpeg) si_save("out/sepal") #change the width si_save("out/sepal.jpeg", width = 5)  }

title: Create Standard SI Plots — si_style
text: function adorns ggplot convert SI style plot. default font Source Sans Pro

title: Create Standard SI Plots — si_style
code: si_style(   font_title,   font_subtitle,   font_plot,   font_caption,   facet_space = 2,   text_scale = 1,   FO = FALSE,   ... )

title: Create Standard SI Plots — si_style
text: font_title font family titles, defaults Source Sans Pro/Arial font_subtitle font family subtitles, defaults Source Sans Pro/Arial font_plot font family plot space, defaults Source Sans Pro/Arial font_caption font family captions, defaults Source Sans Pro/Arial facet_space controls far apart facets text_scale scalar grow/shrink text defined within FO make everything black (, knows) ... pass parameters theme already defined within

title: Create Standard SI Plots — si_style
code: if (FALSE) { library(systemfonts) library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, colour = Species)) +   geom_point() + si_style()   }

title: Create Standard SI Map — si_style_map
code: if (FALSE) {  library(systemfonts) library(tidyverse) library(glitr) library(gisr) library(sf)  sfdf <- gisr::get_admin1("Nigeria") %>%  select(name) %>%  mutate(value = runif(nrow(.), 0, 1))  ggplot() +    geom_sf(data = sfdf,            aes(fill = value),            color = grey10k,            size = .1) +    scale_fill_si(palette = "genoas",                  discrete = FALSE,                  limits = c(0, 1),                  labels = scales::percent) +    labs(title = "NIGERIA - % OF PLHIV BY STATE",         subtitle = "States from XYZ Region are the most hit by HIV/AIDS",         caption = base::paste0("Produced by OHA/SIEI/SI, ON ", base::Sys.Date())) +   si_style_map() +   si_legend_fill() }

title: glitr 0.2
text: Modify colors Hemsworth palette based feedback - midnight_blue, slate, lavender_haze [2024-06-06] Add hw_slate extend Hemsworth palette & add hemsworth option si_palettes [2024-02-11] Change instructions install rOpenSci [2024-01-04] Update font vignette describe changing graphic options [2023-12-12] Add Hemsworth palette (hw_*) testing [2023-12-11] Add new Patone 2024 color year [2023-12-07] Resolve bug extrafonts warning [2023-11-15] Flag extrafonts loaded suggest removal restart [2023-10-17] Update vignettes examples systemfonts [2023-10-27] Implement site build via GitHub Action [2023-10-27] Replace use extrafont systemfonts work efficiently across platforms obviated need stick old version Rttf2pt1 [2023-10-23] Change default font look use either Source Sans 3 (preferred) Source Sans Pro [2023-09-07]

title: glitr 0.1.1
text: Add documentation Tableau TPS file rendered data-raw documentaiton purposes [2023-10-05] Adds si_preview output png see looks iteration stage well si_clear_preview can used clear temporary folder [2023-02-15] Include Pantone Color Year palette color vignette [2023-01-23] Update README font installation instructions duplicated vignette [2023-01-23] Provide alternative font Source Sans Pro available [2022-08-15] Add package status check gagglr [2022-08-15] Update data reflect new naming conventions FY22Q2 (2022-04-08)

title: glitr 0.1.0
text: Added new masked dataset training/demoing, hfr_mmd FO = TRUE sets text black throughout

title: glitr 0.0.1
text: Allows passing theme elements defined si_style() si_legend_fill() adds fill-based legend si_legend_color() adds color-based legend facet_space lets change space facets text_scale allows scaling text size entire plot

title: glitr 0.0.0.9000
text: Add white background plots rather tranparent Migrate website Fix scale_fill_si scale_color_si defaults Renamed color stubs (old si_ colors) siei_ Started vignetted use glitr themes colors
